articles.author: Harshit Singh
articles.description:
Introduction: The Automation Revolution


Ever pushed code to production only to discover a critical bug that could‚Äôve been caught earlier? In 2024, companies using CI/CD pipelines with Jenkins reduced deployment failures by 85%, delivering software faster and more reliably. Jenkins, the open-source automation server, is the backbone of modern DevOps, enabling teams to automate building, testing, and deploying code. Whether you‚Äôre a beginner learning to streamline your Java app or a DevOps pro orchestrating complex microservices, Jenkins transforms chaotic workflows into seamless automation, saving time and boosting confidence in your releases.
This article is your ultimate guide to CI/CD with Jenkins: Automate Everything, following a developer‚Äôs journey from manual chaos to automation mas‚Ä¶
articles.title: CI/CD with Jenkins: Automate Everything

"[${error.errorCode}] " ${error.fieldId} " ${this.getMessage(error.errorCode)}"
`).join(''); va‚Ä¶

articles.author: Dat One Dev
articles.description:
Introduction


There are multiple ways to learn something. Some prefer to learn by practice, some prefer to learn by reading, some prefer to learn by studying, and some prefer to learn by watching.
When I want to learn something, I usually either learn it by practice (Like I am doing with GO 101) or by reading/watching (mostly official stuff), but when it comes to teaching, I prefer to teach things with humour, with comedy and a sparkle of fun. 
For example, recently I have been working on one of my projects called Atomicity. It's a game about chemistry and stuff. One of the reasons for making this game was that I like chemistry, but people don't. 
Similar things can be observed in programming. I like GO and Miniscript more than Python, but someone may like Python more.
And the only reason‚Ä¶
articles.title: Pastopia: When Gaming Meets Coding

articles.author: Rahul Gupta
articles.description:
NativePHP is opening up a new era for Laravel developers‚Äîbringing the elegance of Laravel to the desktop world. But how exactly does it all work under the hood?
In this article, we‚Äôll take a peek behind the curtain and explore how NativePHP blends Laravel with Electron to deliver powerful, native-feeling desktop apps.
At its core, NativePHP is a Laravel package that allows you to build desktop applications using familiar Laravel syntax. But rather than reinventing the wheel, it cleverly leverages Electron, a popular framework that powers apps like VS Code, Slack, and Figma.
So what NativePHP really does is:
Act as a bridge between Laravel (backend) and Electron (frontend).


Abstract away the complexity of managing Electron from Laravel.


Let you define window properties, menus, tray icon‚Ä¶
articles.title: Laravel + Electron = Native Power: How NativePHP Works Under the Hood

articles.author: Akshay Joshi
articles.description:
When we started DoozieSoft in 2013, we were two people with conviction but no capital. We watched startups raise millions for ideas we quietly implemented as client features. While the ecosystem was chasing unicorns, we were chasing customer satisfaction ‚Äî one deliverable at a time. We never took investor money, never skipped a salary, and never compromised on quality. That decision slowed us down, but it also gave us something rare: control.
Over the years, we built internal tools to improve how we worked ‚Äî communication assistants, invoice processors, smart form engines. They were never meant to be products, but every time we used them, we realized: we‚Äôre sitting on real value. DoozieGPT Labs was born from this realization ‚Äî a focused effort to turn our internal AI experiments into usable, scalable, India-first solutions.
This isn‚Äôt a pivot. It‚Äôs a parallel engine. One that draws from over a decade of enterprise delivery, powered by a team that knows how to ship under constraints. Our AI stack blends the best of hosted models (OpenAI, Gemini) with self-hosted LLMs (Ollama), tied together by Laravel, .NET, Python, and pragmatic workflows. We‚Äôre not chasing virality ‚Äî we‚Äôre building tools that help real businesses do more with less.
SayBetter helps teams write with empathy. DoozFlow is bringing intelligence to invoice automation. Phoenix is our long-term bet ‚Äî a full AI-native platform that can serve SMEs without vendor lock-in.
We didn‚Äôt miss the boat. We chose to build our own.
And now, through DoozieGPT Labs, we‚Äôre ready to bring to the world what we've been quietly building for ourselves ‚Äî one purposeful tool at a time.
articles.title: Why We‚Äôre Building DoozieGPT Labs

articles.author: Ismoil Rahmonov
articles.description:
Hangzhou, China ‚Äì May 2025

In a time where international shipping is more important than ever, one computer science student is bringing real-world impact through code ‚Äî by helping customers in Tajikistan track their shipments from China with just a Telegram message.
Meet Ismoil Rahmonov, a student at Hangzhou Dianzi University, who created @cjcargotj_bot, an AI-powered Telegram bot that serves as the digital assistant for CJCARGO Khujand, a cargo delivery company specializing in China‚ÄìTajikistan logistics.
Ismoil realized that many families in Tajikistan order goods from China but have little visibility on their shipment status ‚Äî especially those who aren't tech-savvy.
‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt want to go to websites and paste tracking numbers. But everyone uses Telegram,‚Äù says Ismoil.
That inspired hi‚Ä¶
articles.title: üéì From Classroom to Cargo: How a Hangzhou Student Built a Telegram Bot to Modernize Central Asian Shipping

articles.author: Charpie
articles.description:
Factory-Floor Lessons in Reshaping Software Innovation



  
  
  ‚ÄçHierarchy on the Floor


In the early 20th century, manufacturing was organized with a rigid hierarchy. Managers and engineers made all significant decisions, while front-line workers were expected to "do as they're told," performing narrow tasks without input into process or strategy. Factory workers, often seen as low-status laborers, had little agency beyond their assigned duties. This division meant that problem-solving and innovation were the sole province of experts and senior staff, not the rank-and-file. By the 1930s, the typical American steel mill or machine shop exemplified this top-down structure. Workers on the shop floor desired better pay and conditions, but companies struggling through the Great Depression h‚Ä¶
articles.title: The Quiet Revolution of Empowered Workers

articles.author: Furqan Ahmad
articles.description:
Introduction


Artificial Intelligence (AI) has emerged as one of the most transformative technologies of our time, reshaping industries, society, and our daily lives. As AI systems become more powerful and pervasive, the need for robust ethical frameworks and governance structures has never been more critical. This article explores the multifaceted domain of AI ethics and governance, examining what it is, why it matters, and how organizations and societies can implement effective governance frameworks to ensure AI technologies benefit humanity while minimizing potential harms.
The rapid advancement of AI capabilities‚Äîfrom machine learning algorithms that can predict consumer behavior to generative AI systems that create content indistinguishable from human work‚Äîpresents both unprecedented‚Ä¶
articles.title: üîíAI Ethics and Governance: A Comprehensive Guide

articles.author: Md Umar Siddique
articles.description:
"JavaScript is a language of many paradigms. It borrows ideas from functional programming, object-oriented programming, and procedural programming." 
Kyle Simpson
Why does JavaScript feel... different?
Every developer has that moment. You're writing code, everything seems logical, and then JavaScript does something that makes you pause and think: "Wait, that actually worked?"
A variable becomes a function.

An object transforms mid-execution.

Async operations flow like water.
Other languages demand you follow their rules. JavaScript asks: "What are you trying to accomplish?" Then it finds a way ‚Äî often multiple ways ‚Äî to make it happen.
This isn't accident. It's intentional design philosophy that emerged from a simple truth: the web is chaotic, unpredictable, and constantly changing. So J‚Ä¶
articles.title: The Philosophy of JavaScript: Messy, Mighty, and Made for the Web

articles.author: Madalina Pastiu
articles.description:
Instructions:


Given two arrays a and b write a function comp(a, b) (orcompSame(a, b)) that checks whether the two arrays have the "same" elements, with the same multiplicities (the multiplicity of a member is the number of times it appears). "Same" means, here, that the elements in b are the elements in a squared, regardless of the order.
Examples

b = [121, 14641, 20736, 361, 25921, 361, 20736, 361]
a = [121, 144, 19, 161, 19, 144, 19, 11] 
a = [121, 144, 19, 161, 19, 144, 19, 11]

b = [132, 14641, 20736, 361, 25921, 361, 20736, 361]
a = [121, 144, 19, 161, 19, 144, 19, 11]

b = [121, 14641, 20736, 36100, 25921, 361, 20736, 361]
Remarks
Thoughts 1:


Initially, I approached the problem by checking if each number from the first array, when squared, exists in the second array. However, du‚Ä¶
articles.title: Are they the "same"?
